title: ENG09_pt 1: 1.2 Richard Connell - "The Most Dangerous Game" | SVHS

mainContent.text:
1.2 Richard Connell - "The Most Dangerous Game"

        Completion requirements
        



The Adventure Short Story
Adventure fiction is closely related to the genres of epic and romance, where there are traditional archetypes, "stock" characters who are easily distinguishable as good or evil.  
"The Most Dangerous Game," is a classic example of escape literature (purely for entertainment) in that there is prolonged conflict between the protagonist (Rainsford) and antagonist (Zaroff).  Even though both Rainsford and Zaroff
    are master hunters and foils (reflections of each other), Zaroff's lust for blood crosses the boundaries of "civilized" society, according to Connell.

"The Most Dangerous Game" is escapist literature at its finest.  Most high school freshman literature books begin with this story because it is high interest and easy to analyze in terms of story elements and a plot diagram.  Though a great
    story, it is essentially a warm-up to more sophisticated texts.  Connell presents Rainsford as an archetypal "action hero."  Or, is he an anti-hero?  Ironically, the story anticipates the future Cold War tensions between Russia (U.S.S.R.)
    and the U.S.A. that would dominate geopolitics for the next century.  The ending is open-ended: does Rainsford learn from his mistakes, or does he become like Zaroff?

Assignment:  Read "The Most Dangerous Game" by Richard Connell.


Watch the following videos as you read the story:








Reading:
Adventure Fiction (genre)
